name: Pranay Aryal's biostatistics site
body: ### Final Exam Study Guide Confidence Intervals A confidence interval is two points (the lower and upper limits) between which the unknown population quantity being estimated lies with a certain probability. Heuristic Formula ğ‘·ğ’ğ’Šğ’ğ’• ğ‘¬ğ’”ğ’•ğ’Šğ’ğ’‚ğ’•ğ’† Â± (ğ‘«ğ’Šğ’”ğ’•ğ’“ğ’Šğ’ƒğ’–ğ’•ğ’Šğ’ğ’ ğ‘·ğ’†ğ’“ğ’„ğ’†ğ’ğ’•ğ’Šğ’ğ’†) Ã— (ğ‘ºğ’•ğ’‚ğ’ğ’…ğ’‚ğ’“ğ’… ğ‘¬ğ’“ğ’“ğ’ğ’“) - Each of the quantities â€“ the point estimate, the percentile, and the standard error â€“ depends on what is being estimated. Consult the formulas on the following pages to see how. - The percentile additionally depends on the level of confidence, (e.g.) 90%, 95%, 99%, etc. - Remember that this heuristic formula does not apply for confidence intervals for variances and ratios of variances. Interpretation The confidence interval contains the unknown population quantity (mean, difference in means, proportion, difference in proportions, etc.) being estimated with a certain probability. More practically speaking, points inside the confidence interval represent â€œplausibleâ€ values for the unknown population quantity. Points outside the confidence interval are not plausible. Confidence intervals are often used with â€œbenchmarkâ€ values for the quantity being estimated. If the benchmark lies in the confidence interval, then the benchmark is a plausible value. If the benchmark lies outside the confidence interval, then the benchmark is not a plausible value. Hypothesis Tests *The Hypothesis Testing Process* Know and be able to execute (most) the steps of the hypothesis testing process: 1. State a research hypothesis 2. Define and evaluate the data 3. Refine a research hypothesis to a statistical hypothesis Identify a suitable test statistic 4. Determine reference distribution for the test statistic State the statistical decision rule 5. Evaluate assumptions about the data 6. Calculate the test statistic 7. Make the statistical decision 8. Calculate p-value and confidence interval *Heuristic Formula* $$\text{Test Statistic}=\frac{\text{Point Estimate - Null Value}}{\text{Standard Error}}$$
